articles.headline: Conceived by Students, a Portfolio That Pays
articles.snippet: Many investors are trying to figure out how to generate income in a time of low interest rates. Some Duke undergraduates think they have the answer.
articles.abstract: Many investors are trying to figure out how to generate income in a time of low interest rates. Some Duke undergraduates think they have the answer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Squeezed by historically low interest rates, a wide range of investors — from retirees living on fixed incomes to huge endowments and pension funds trying to meet budgets — are trying to figure out how to generate income.

articles.headline: Birth Control Rule Altered to Allay Religious Objections
articles.snippet: The Obama administration proposed a compromise that it said would guarantee free coverage of birth control while allowing churches and religious organizations not to pay for it.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration proposed a compromise that it said would guarantee free coverage of birth control while allowing churches and religious organizations not to pay for it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday proposed yet another compromise to address strenuous objections from religious organizations about a policy requiring health insurance plans to provide free contraceptives, but the change did not end the political furor or legal fight over the issue.

articles.headline: Diocese Papers in Los Angeles Detail Decades of Abuse
articles.snippet: Cardinal Roger Mahony, the former archbishop of Los Angeles, insisted that his approach to sexual abuse had evolved as he learned more over the years.
articles.abstract: Cardinal Roger Mahony, the former archbishop of Los Angeles, insisted that his approach to sexual abuse had evolved as he learned more over the years.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The church files are filled with outrage, pain and confusion. There are handwritten notes from distraught mothers, accounts of furious phone calls from brothers and perplexed inquiries from the police following up on allegations of priests sexually abusing children.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Medina and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: Signs That It’s Time for a New Broker
articles.snippet: A recent case of a stockbroker with Wells Fargo who stole from his customers is a cautionary tale for all investors.
articles.abstract: A recent case of a stockbroker with Wells Fargo who stole from his customers is a cautionary tale for all investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every so often, a story so perfectly illustrates what can go wrong when you trust someone with your money that it serves as a kind of user’s manual for any investor who comes along afterward.

articles.headline: Brothers Develop New Device to Halt Allergy Attacks
articles.snippet: A quest that two brothers with severe food allergies began 15 years ago has culminated in a new device to inject epinephrine in the event of a severe allergic reaction.
articles.abstract: A quest that two brothers with severe food allergies began 15 years ago has culminated in a new device to inject epinephrine in the event of a severe allergic reaction.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twin brothers Eric and Evan Edwards grew up with serious food allergies and were under doctor’s orders to carry their medicine everywhere they went.

articles.headline: F.T.C. Suggests Privacy Guidelines for Mobile Apps
articles.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission said the mobile industry should include a do-not-track feature in software and apps and take other steps to safeguard personal information.
articles.abstract: The Federal Trade Commission said the mobile industry should include a do-not-track feature in software and apps and take other steps to safeguard personal information.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a strong move to protect the privacy of Americans as they use the Internet on their smartphones and tablets, the Federal Trade Commission on Friday said the mobile industry should include a do-not-track feature in software and apps and take other steps to safeguard personal information.

articles.headline: Investigators Begin to Test Other Electrical Parts on the 787
articles.snippet: Regulators in Washington and Tokyo said they had no answers to explain why two batteries on Boeing’s troubled Dreamliner emitted fire or smoke.
articles.abstract: Regulators in Washington and Tokyo said they had no answers to explain why two batteries on Boeing’s troubled Dreamliner emitted fire or smoke.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investigators have not found enough evidence in the charred remains of two Boeing 787 batteries to determine why they overheated, and they are expanding their examination of other electrical components, regulators in Washington and Tokyo said on Friday.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Christopher Drew

articles.headline: As U.S. Growth Lags, Some Press the Fed to Do Still More
articles.snippet: Federal Reserve officials believe the bank could do more to increase the pace of inflation and aid growth. They simply are not persuaded that the benefits outweigh potential costs.
articles.abstract: Federal Reserve officials believe the bank could do more to increase the pace of inflation and aid growth. They simply are not persuaded that the benefits outweigh potential costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the five months since the Federal Reserve started a campaign to increase growth and reduce unemployment, the economy has slowed and unemployment has increased.

articles.headline: First Pull-Ups, Then Combat, Marines Say
articles.snippet: The announcement last week ending the ban on women in combat only accelerated a sweeping re-examination of fitness standards in the American military.
articles.abstract: The announcement last week ending the ban on women in combat only accelerated a sweeping re-examination of fitness standards in the American military.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — How many pull-ups does it take to make a female Marine?

articles.headline:
Algeria Sowed Seeds
of Hostage Crisis as
It Nurtured Warlord
articles.snippet: Algeria’s antiterrorism policy of playing favorites among armed groups like Ansar Dine, founded by Iyad Ag Ghali, backfired last month when extremists seized a gas field.
articles.abstract: Algeria’s antiterrorism policy of playing favorites among armed groups like Ansar Dine, founded by Iyad Ag Ghali, backfired last month when extremists seized a gas field.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALGIERS — To the Algerians, the desert warlord in the swirling blue robes was a man of his word — the key to managing the crisis next door in northern Mali — and for months they lodged his representative here in the Algerian capital in high style in one of the city’s finest hotels.
articles.byline: By Adam Nossiter and Neil MacFarquhar

articles.headline: Backstage Glimpses of Clinton as Dogged Diplomat, Win or Lose
articles.snippet: The instincts of Hillary Rodham Clinton, the departing secretary of state, were often more activist than those of a White House that has kept a tight grip on foreign policy.
articles.abstract: The instincts of Hillary Rodham Clinton, the departing secretary of state, were often more activist than those of a White House that has kept a tight grip on foreign policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last summer, as the fighting in Syria raged and questions about the United States’ inaction grew, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton conferred privately with David H. Petraeus, the director of the C.I.A. The two officials were joining forces on a plan to arm the Syrian resistance.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Banks, at Least, Had a Friend in Geithner
articles.snippet: Timothy F. Geithner, who is leaving as Treasury secretary, helped America’s big banks get back on their feet after the financial crisis. But how much did he do to prevent future debacles?
articles.abstract: Timothy F. Geithner, who is leaving as Treasury secretary, helped America’s big banks get back on their feet after the financial crisis. But how much did he do to prevent future debacles?
articles.lead_paragraph: TIMOTHY F. GEITHNER left the Treasury Department last week after four years as secretary. So how did he do?

articles.headline: Wall St. Is Pounding on Avon’s Door
articles.snippet: One analyst says Avon “seems to be the perennial turnaround story.” But the company is making a new effort to regain investors’ favor.
articles.abstract: One analyst says Avon “seems to be the perennial turnaround story.” But the company is making a new effort to regain investors’ favor.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOME C.E.O.’s are tough acts to follow. Andrea Jung isn’t one of them.

articles.headline: The Most Wanted Gun in America
articles.snippet: Aggressive marketing and savvy manufacturing have helped recast the place of guns in American life, turning AR-15-style rifles into a fast-growing profit center.
articles.abstract: Aggressive marketing and savvy manufacturing have helped recast the place of guns in American life, turning AR-15-style rifles into a fast-growing profit center.
articles.lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Md.

articles.headline: In Hard Economy for All Ages, Older Isn’t Better ... It’s Brutal
articles.snippet: Recent data present a strong case for baby boomers as the greatest victims of the recession and its grim aftermath.
articles.abstract: Recent data present a strong case for baby boomers as the greatest victims of the recession and its grim aftermath.
articles.lead_paragraph: Young graduates are in debt, out of work and on their parents’ couches. People in their 30s and 40s can’t afford to buy homes or have children. Retirees are earning near-zero interest on their savings.

articles.headline: Militants’ Goal in Algeria Gas Plant Siege: Giant Fireball
articles.snippet: Heavily armed fighters who seized a desert complex on Jan. 16 sought to turn the forest of pipes and tubes into a bomb. What none of them knew was how, in the vast maze of metal, to do it.
articles.abstract: Heavily armed fighters who seized a desert complex on Jan. 16 sought to turn the forest of pipes and tubes into a bomb. What none of them knew was how, in the vast maze of metal, to do it.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIGUENTOURINE, Algeria — The goal of the heavily armed militants who seized the desert gas plant here is becoming increasingly clear: to turn the forest of pipes and tubes into a giant bomb, and to blow up everything and anyone around. What none of them knew was exactly how, in the endless maze of metal, to do it.
articles.byline: By Adam Nossiter and Nicholas Kulish

articles.headline: Drowned in a Stream of Prescriptions
articles.snippet: A young man’s suicide highlights issues in the treatment of A.D.H.D., as youths fake symptoms to feed their addictions to potentially dangerous stimulants.
articles.abstract: A young man’s suicide highlights issues in the treatment of A.D.H.D., as youths fake symptoms to feed their addictions to potentially dangerous stimulants.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIRGINIA BEACH — Every morning on her way to work, Kathy Fee holds her breath as she drives past the squat brick building that houses Dominion Psychiatric Associates.

articles.headline: Top Donors to Republicans Seek More Say in Senate Races
articles.snippet: The Republican Party’s biggest donors are financing a new group to recruit seasoned candidates and protect Senate incumbents from challenges by far-right conservatives and Tea Party enthusiasts.
articles.abstract: The Republican Party’s biggest donors are financing a new group to recruit seasoned candidates and protect Senate incumbents from challenges by far-right conservatives and Tea Party enthusiasts.
articles.lead_paragraph: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa — The biggest donors in the Republican Party are financing a new group to recruit seasoned candidates and protect Senate incumbents from challenges by far-right conservatives and Tea Party enthusiasts who Republican leaders worry could complicate the party’s efforts to win control of the Senate.

articles.headline: Untouchable in Iraq, Ex-Sniper Dies in a Shooting Back Home
articles.snippet: Chris Kyle, a former Navy SEAL, had taken a troubled fellow veteran to a gun range for a kind of therapy session, but the police said the man turned his gun on Mr. Kyle.
articles.abstract: Chris Kyle, a former Navy SEAL, had taken a troubled fellow veteran to a gun range for a kind of therapy session, but the police said the man turned his gun on Mr. Kyle.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — From his perch in hide-outs above battle-scarred Iraq, Chris Kyle earned a reputation as one of America’s deadliest military snipers. The Pentagon said his skills with a rifle so terrorized Iraqi insurgents during his four tours of duty that they nicknamed him the “Devil of Ramadi” and put a bounty on his head.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and Michael Schwirtz

articles.headline: Shunning the Safe, FX Indulges Its Dark Side
articles.snippet: Behind FX’s recent success is its willingness to give its shows creative freedom.
articles.abstract: Behind FX’s recent success is its willingness to give its shows creative freedom.
articles.lead_paragraph: The FX channel can be a rugged place, full of prostitutes, charlatans, spies, bikers and thugs. But it’s a nice place if you are trying to make a show.

articles.headline: Once BlackBerry Focused, a Campus Widens Its View
articles.snippet: The University of Waterloo, a world-class engineering school in Canada, is a feeder campus for big-name global tech companies like BlackBerry, a neighbor and Waterloo offshoot.
articles.abstract: The University of Waterloo, a world-class engineering school in Canada, is a feeder campus for big-name global tech companies like BlackBerry, a neighbor and Waterloo offshoot.
articles.lead_paragraph: WATERLOO, Ontario — The University of Waterloo, in a city that people outside Canada would struggle to find on a map, is one of the world’s best technology schools.

articles.headline: Teen Vogue, a Survivor at 10 Years
articles.snippet: The magazine has outlasted a string of rivals in a sector notable for its audience outgrowing it every few years.
articles.abstract: The magazine has outlasted a string of rivals in a sector notable for its audience outgrowing it every few years.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a long day of classes, homework and college preparation, Susannah Davies, a 17-year-old high school junior, takes a break by flipping through her print copy of Teen Vogue, the fashion magazine she has subscribed to since the sixth grade.

articles.headline: Broad Powers Seen for Obama in Cyberstrikes
articles.snippet: The administration is moving to approve the nation’s first rules for how the military can defend, or retaliate, against a major cyberattack.
articles.abstract: The administration is moving to approve the nation’s first rules for how the military can defend, or retaliate, against a major cyberattack.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A secret legal review on the use of America’s growing arsenal of cyberweapons has concluded that President Obama has the broad power to order a pre-emptive strike if the United States detects credible evidence of a major digital attack looming from abroad, according to officials involved in the review.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Film Financier Faces a Critical Juncture
articles.snippet: Time will tell if Thomas Tull, one of the most successful walk-on players in movie history, really is the latest outsider to win an insider’s game through his company, Legendary Entertainment.
articles.abstract: Time will tell if Thomas Tull, one of the most successful walk-on players in movie history, really is the latest outsider to win an insider’s game through his company, Legendary Entertainment.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — During the baseball strike of 1995, Thomas Tull, then a 24-year-old laundromat owner, was audacious enough to turn up at a training camp for the Atlanta Braves. They looked at his swing and sent him home.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply

articles.headline: Rise in Oil Tax Forces Greeks to Face Cold as Ancients Did
articles.snippet: After a 450 percent increase, many residents have switched to firewood but still cannot keep warm, as smoke and logging raise environmental worries.
articles.abstract: After a 450 percent increase, many residents have switched to firewood but still cannot keep warm, as smoke and logging raise environmental worries.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Even in the leafy northern stretches of this city, home to luxury apartment buildings, mansions with swimming pools and tennis clubs, the smell of wood smoke lingers everywhere at night.

articles.headline: New Details Suggest a Defense in SAC Case
articles.snippet: Internal trading records also raise questions on whether the government will be able to build a case against Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire owner of the hedge fund.
articles.abstract: Internal trading records also raise questions on whether the government will be able to build a case against Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire owner of the hedge fund.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the center of the government’s insider trading case against a former portfolio manager at the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors is a trade that directly involves Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire owner of the fund.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Peter Lattman

articles.headline: Fresh Questions Over a Bank of America Settlement
articles.snippet: The bank continued dubious mortgage modification practices even after its acquisition of Countrywide, court documents show.
articles.abstract: The bank continued dubious mortgage modification practices even after its acquisition of Countrywide, court documents show.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank of America has long rued its decision in 2008 to acquire Countrywide Financial, the subprime mortgage giant. To date, the bank has set aside some $40 billion to settle claims of mortgage misconduct that occurred before it acquired the freewheeling lender.

articles.headline: As Extremists Invaded, Timbuktu Hid Artifacts of a Golden Age
articles.snippet: Residents found ways to hide delicate artifacts from the Islamists who reigned over the city until last weekend, when fighters set fire to dozens of ancient manuscripts.
articles.abstract: Residents found ways to hide delicate artifacts from the Islamists who reigned over the city until last weekend, when fighters set fire to dozens of ancient manuscripts.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIMBUKTU, Mali — When the moment of danger came, Ali Imam Ben Essayouti knew just what to do. The delicate, unbound parchment manuscripts in the 14th-century mosque he leads had already survived hundreds of years in the storied city of Timbuktu. He was not about to allow its latest invaders, Tuareg nationalist rebels and Islamic extremists from across the region, to destroy them now.
